teaching_point: Narrow CIs require much larger samples for precise estimation
Narrower CIs need more subjects than wider CIs
Standard CI width (Â±0.10) provides reasonable precision with moderate n
Wider CIs acceptable for pilot studies require fewer subjects

expected_pattern: Larger sample needed for low kappa
teaching_point: Lower kappa values have higher variance, requiring larger samples
Moderate kappa has moderate variance

expected_pattern: Smaller sample needed for high kappa
teaching_point: Higher kappa values have lower variance, requiring fewer subjects
Very high kappa has low variance, minimal sample needed
90% CI requires fewer subjects than 95% CI
95% CI is standard for most clinical studies
99% CI requires more subjects for same precision
Higher confidence levels need substantially more subjects
Two raters is most common and efficient design
Three raters provide more information per subject
Multiple raters can reduce required subjects but increase cost
Many raters provide rich data but practical constraints apply
Balanced proportions maximize statistical efficiency
Moderate imbalance increases sample size modestly
Rare outcomes require substantially more subjects for same precision
Extremely rare outcomes dramatically increase required sample size
Binary outcomes have simplest structure
More categories increase complexity and sample requirements
Additional categories further increase sample size
Many categories require most subjects for same precision
